summary: The Instagram account @natgeo showcases a diverse range of visually compelling content, primarily focusing on nature, wildlife, and scientific exploration. The posts often feature striking photography highlighting both the beauty and fragility of the natural world. There's an emphasis on conservation efforts and the impact of human activities on the environment. Some posts promote National Geographic documentaries and series. The potential for controversy exists in posts that depict sensitive topics such as animal welfare, scientific ethics, or environmental impact.

posts.caption:
National Geographic photographers have spent the past year documenting the world in all its beauty and complexity. Out of hundreds of thousands of photos, 25 were selected as our Pictures of the Year. üì∏

From once-in-a-lifetime phenomena to elusive animals to pioneering science, view these special moments featuring rare wildlife, scientific discoveries, and human exploration at the link in bio.

Photograph 1 by Anand Varma, photograph 2 by @johnstanmeyer, photograph 3 by @stephenwilkes
posts.flag_reason: The image of the developing embryo inside the egg could be potentially controversial for those sensitive about animal welfare or the representation of life.
posts.image_description: The Instagram image features a close-up photo of an egg, with the inside showing red veins and a yellowish glow, encased by a translucent shell against a black background. Text overlay announces "See our Pictures of the Year 2025," and the National Geographic logo is visible in the lower right corner. The image of the developing embryo could be potentially controversial for those sensitive about animal welfare or the representation of life.

posts.caption:
You can do everything ‚Äúright‚Äù before bed and still wake up tired‚Äîsomething sleep researchers say isn‚Äôt always about stress or routines. Research shows that your pillow‚Äôs height and firmness can impact how your body is supported during sleep, how easily the brain reaches deeper sleep, and affect overall sleep quality.

Learn how to choose the pillow that's right for your sleep style at the link in bio. 

Photograph by Eloise Ramos, Stocksy
posts.image_description: The image is an advertisement, likely for a sleep product, featuring a person in orange pajamas holding a huge stack of white pillows in front of their face.  The text overlay above states, "The wrong pillow can wreck your sleep. Science can help you find the right one," implying a scientific solution to sleep problems. The National Geographic logo in the corner subtly lends credibility to the scientific aspect.

posts.caption:
Nat Geo photographer @brianskerry has logged more than 10,000 hours underwater, but the encounter that led to this image from our Pictures of the Year 2025 was unlike any other. He photographed this great white shark off Maine's coast from just four feet away. Sightings of sharks like this 10-footer are increasing from Cape Cod to Nova Scotia, due in part to the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972, which allowed seal populations to rebound.

National Geographic photographers ventured to places far and wide to capture the year‚Äôs most fascinating images. Out of hundreds of thousands of photos, 25 were selected as our Pictures of the Year. See them all at the link in bio.
posts.flag_reason: The image description mentions potential controversy stemming from the discussion of shark feeding and conservation surrounding great white sharks.
posts.image_description: The image is an underwater shot of a great white shark, its mouth slightly open revealing rows of teeth. The shark is in murky green water, with its reflection visible on the water's surface above. The potential controversy stems from the discussion of shark feeding and conservation surrounding great white sharks.

posts.caption: Photo by @joshuacogan | A honu‚ÄîHawaiian green sea turtle‚Äîglides among blossoms in Kaloko-Honok≈çhau National Historical Park. Once on the brink of extinction due to habitat loss, these ancient mariners began a remarkable comeback in the 1970s through protections and local conservation. Though challenges like pollution and climate change remain, their return reflects the power of science, culture, and stewardship. In Hawaiian tradition, the honu symbolizes wisdom and perseverance. It is often regarded as an ‚ÄòaumƒÅkua, or ancestral guardian. To see one in the wild is to witness resilience in motion, a reminder to keep moving forward. | See how these turtles mirror a similar story of perseverance in Ho‚Äôomau: Joey‚Äôs Journey, proudly presented by argenx. Watch Joey, who has CIDP (chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy), explore Hawaii and continue to pursue a passion for travel while living with a rare disease. Stream now on @hulu.
posts.flag_reason: Placing flowers in the habitat of the turtle could be potentially harmful to the local wildlife.
posts.image_description: The image features a sea turtle swimming in shallow, clear water dotted with vibrant orange blossoms. The turtle is positioned in the center of the frame, surrounded by a sandy and rocky seabed visible through the water. Placing flowers in the habitat of the turtle could be potentially harmful to the local wildlife.

posts.caption:
It took @willsmith 100 days to travel from one pole to the other, but you can make that journey in a few swipes. üì≤

#PoleToPole with Will Smith premieres January 13 at 9/8c on National Geographic. Streaming on @DisneyPlus and @hulu.
posts.flag_reason: The image description notes that the post could spark debate about environmental impact or accessibility of remote locations.
posts.image_description: The Instagram image shows a man dressed in bright yellow and black cold weather gear, standing on a vast expanse of icy terrain holding ski poles. The text overlay at the bottom of the image reads "FOLLOW WILL SMITH'S JOURNEY POLE TO POLE," suggesting he may be embarking on a journey to the North and South Poles, which could spark debate about environmental impact or accessibility of remote locations.
